choices.text:
### Human:
Tom washed 10 pairs of socks. The socks are now wet from the wash, so Tom hangs the 10 pairs of socks outside to dry. 10 hours later, he comes back outside to check on the socks. He feels each sock and notices they are all dry. He takes them back inside because they are all dry. How long will it take Tom to dry seven pairs of socks presuming the same weather conditions?
### Assistant:

To solve this problem, we need to use the following formula: 
Time = (Number of items) / (Rate of drying)
We know that Tom dried 10 pairs of socks in 10 hours. So, we can set up the equation as follows:
10 hours = (Number of pairs of socks) / (Rate of drying)
Simplifying this equation, we get:
10 hours = Number of pairs of socks
Now that we have an expression for the time it takes to dry 10 pairs of socks, we can use it to find out how long it will take Tom to dry seven pairs of socks. We know that each pair of socks takes the same amount of time to dry as one pair of socks, so we can set up the equation as follows:
Time = (Number of pairs of socks) / (Rate of drying)
We want to find out how long it will take Tom to dry seven pairs of socks. So, we can substitute 7 for Number of pairs of socks and solve for Time:
Time = 7 / (Rate of drying)
Simplifying this equation, we get:
Time = 7 hours
Therefore, it will take Tom 7 hours to dry seven pairs of socks presuming the same weather conditions.
